label: real
article:
A country without any new infections. How is it possible? The man charged with combatting the virus explains the Australian recipe for success – and what Germany can learn from it.
Lesen Sie diesen Text auf Deutsch
DIE ZEIT: Professor Sutton, you’re so
popular in Australia that people are buying mugs, socks, ties and bedding with
your picture on them. Do you own any of them? 
Brett Sutton: No, I don’t. I am a
public health physician, I’ve done humanitarian work overseas but I have not
been such a public figure previously. And so it is just a strange and rather comical position to be in to have
this strange attention. I think a lot of public health people have become
celebrities, either in a positive way or in a negative way, or both. And I
think I am in the category of both. There are people who are also very angry
about what we have been through and what we have experienced here in Melbourne
and in Victoria more broadly. 
ZEIT: What is the most important advice you have given since the outbreak of the
pandemic?
Sutton: I think the most important advice or request, or message of trust was that
we will get through this. It is going to be hard, it is going to be long, but we know where we are
headed and we are very clear where we want to get to. I think we have stuck to that
promise. We had a short sharp lockdown, a circuit breaker, as we have called it, this last week
after an outbreak of 22 cases. But we have isolated the case, we have
identified all close contacts. It is very conservative, but it is with a view to again to being able to open up and go back to a relatively
normal life. 
ZEIT: Was that the decisive factor in the long lockdown last year which lasted
more than 100 days? 
Sutton: For us, it was clear that the rest of the country had achieved no
community transmission, and so, of course, we were reflecting on needing to
protect the rest of the country by getting to the same position. It was the
only sustainable strategy. If we don’t get to a point where you manage the few
cases that might arise, then you are always dealing with social distancing,
mask wearing, and a whole bunch of other restrictions on society that are
probably not sustainable in the long term.
ZEIT: Is a lot of testing being carried out in Australia?
Sutton: The testing per capita is very high. For my own state in Victoria, we have
got over 200 testing sites. They are mostly drive-through as well as being able
to go to a local general practitioner and some hospital-based respiratory
clinics. And for a population of almost 7 million, we have about 20,000 to 30,000
tests per day, so, it is very high.
ZEIT: And when did you start testing?
Sutton: Right from the beginning. Victoria has a reference laboratory, the
Victorian Infectious Disease Reference Laboratory, which was the first place outside
of China to sequence the virus and create a test that allowed for PCR testing. Our PCR test was
in place in January 2020.
ZEIT: You have probably seen that in Germany we are only now starting to carry
out large-scale testing and a lot of people are asking why this has taken so
long. 
Sutton: It took us a while to be able to scale up the testing capacity. It was
literally just in the hundreds for the first few months, and it would have
gotten beyond us in March and April, if we hadn’t had a mandatory quarantine
programme. But with the combination of those restrictions, the quarantine and
the testing, it was manageable. But I think the difference in Europe and North America is that cases continue to grow exponentially and the testing couldn’t
keep up with it.
ZEIT: You suspended international air travel, closed schools, only allowed
people to leave their homes to run essential errands and indoor socialising was
banned. How did you convince people that these tough restrictions were the
right approach?  
Sutton: I think a fortunate aspect was that when we were asking that of
Victorians, they had already seen that elimination was achievable in other states and
territories. I think the key components were that we were very clear with the ultimate objective which
was to be free of Covid in the community for the longer term. Daniel Andrews,
the Premier of Victoria reinforced those messages each and every day. The other
element that was very helpful was a modelling that predicted that we would be able to get to our threshold level for lifting restrictions on a certain
date. And then, everyone followed the numbers every day and could see that it
was more or less on track.
ZEIT: Looking back, what measures were the hardest to implement? 
Sutton: I think people clearly struggled as you would expect with the social
isolation. There are a number of people who lived alone normally and I think
the struggle was even more substantial for them.
ZEIT: Was there an increase in mental health problems during the lockdown? Or in
domestic violence?
Sutton: We saw increased calls to Lifeline which is the national number for people
struggling with mental health, suicidal ideation. We saw an increase in calls to
the domestic violence hotline as well. The true rate of suicide did not
increase during that period. Any suicide is one to many. We knew that there was
a psychological cost to it. But of course we were reflecting on what the
alternative was, and if there was a need for repeated lockdowns, as Europe has
experienced, we knew that that would have had a toll at least as great.
ZEIT: But criticism of the government’s hard line has grown louder, for
instance, when 22 cases sent a whole state into a strict lockdown – an outbreak
which would seem relatively harmless compared to the numbers in Europe. 
Sutton: Every epidemic in every country started with one case, and of course, if
you have only got one or two dozen cases, you are not going to see deaths, you
are not going to see your health system overwhelmed. But if you wait until your
health system is overwhelmed, you will never get to a position where you can
control numbers in the long term again. Victoria has had 820 deaths in total
and that is a real tragedy. But in a sense, there are many places in Europe and
North America now that are so used to high numbers of deaths that they can’t
even reflect on how tragic that scale of dying is. The day before this
interview I read a headline from the Daily Mail in the UK, calling for an end
to the lockdown in England, and then I saw there were 500 deaths per day, and
over 10,000 cases per day.
ZEIT: Is it possible to ‘live with the virus’ as has been discussed in Germany
or does it have to be eradicated? 
Sutton: The prospect of living with the virus is an awful alternative. It means
hundreds of deaths and the long-term effects of long Covid that we are only now
starting to understand.
ZEIT: Could your strategy be followed by other countries?
Sutton: I think so. I do think that the lessons are probably that if you can have
a period of lockdown, of significant restrictions, to drive community transmission
in the local area to a very low level, it allows the test, trace and isolate
systems to work. At the same time, I recognize that we are not talking about coming down from 675 cases a day for many countries. We are
talking about coming down from 10,000 or 15,000 cases per day. That would
suggest that you need maybe twelve months of lockdown to drive down to a
sustainable level. So I don’t pretend for a minute that what we have done in
Victoria or in Australia is necessarily applicable to Europe as a whole.
ZEIT: But...
Sutton: But I do think there must be places within Europe, within Germany, where
there are relatively low levels of transmission that could be driven down to zero. Strategically it
could be an option to have a strict restriction in place for movement in and
out of the region. Australia has shown it can work.
ZEIT: But Australia is a sparsely populated country without any land borders,
while Germany is much more densely populated and in the middle of Europe. 
Sutton: There is some truth in it but it is not the whole story. It is also the
case that Thailand and Vietnam which have land borders and very dense
populations have also managed to end community transmission. I am sure that
Germany’s mobile population across a relatively small geographical area
compared to Australia probably makes it harder to lockdown individual areas or
regions. Australia does have a high population density within its state and
territory capital cities but we have still been able to manage internal
borders.
ZEIT: A group of scientists is now calling for Germany to adopt the Australian
approach and follow a ‘No Covid strategy’. What do you think of this idea? 
Sutton: So again, I think that there are now very significant challenges with
thousands of cases per day and it may be that it would simply take too long to
drive down numbers to a sustainable level. And it may be that getting
vaccinations rolled out faster, more substantially to the at-risk population is
going to achieve those objectives faster than a lockdown would. But I think
there are probably some regions where this approach could be applied, where
regional borders internally and formal quarantine systems would work. I think
you need a mix of different measures to combat the consistently high levels of
new infections.
ZEIT: In Germany the ‘No Covid strategy’ is often countered with a number of
arguments which I would like to discuss with you. The first one is: it’s
impossible to ensure everyone complies with these strict rules.
Sutton: I would disagree with that. I think we did achieve that in Victoria. But I
do accept that in Europe there might be more behavioural fatigue because there
have been rolling lockdowns over a 13-month period, and it becomes much, much
harder to say we just need to do another four months of very strict lockdown or
three months. 
ZEIT: The second counter argument: No Covid requires an authoritarian approach
which doesn’t work in a democracy.
Sutton: New Zealand has done it, Australia has done it, there are other places
that have done it that are clearly democratic countries. The idea that we would
even restrict people to their homes and limit their exercise, time to go
shopping for just an hour a day was probably not able to be imagined, but then
these are things that we hadn’t imagined before Covid.  Clearly, people were willing to do them. So, I
think it is not true that a democracy doesn’t allow for that. It depends how
you value life and health against those freedoms.
ZEIT: The third argument says it’s impossible to keep the incidence rate
permanently at zero or almost zero 
Sutton: if you can get to a level that is sustainable through test, trace and
isolate, then I think it might be achievable. Whether it works will depend on
your contact tracing workforce, your systems for capturing that information,
your testing capacity and capability, and peoples’ willingness to home quarantine,
if they are close contacts.
ZEIT: Last argument: A No Covid strategy damages the economy
Sutton: I think this argument is completely wrong. Those countries that have
managed to control transmission have done better economically. I have seen research
that most of the economic activity is not constrained by lockdowns, but by
peoples’ own changed behaviour because of very high levels of transmission and
the huge economic and societal costs as a result of people who can’t work, who
are unwell, who are hospitalized and who are dying.
ZEIT: Almost a year ago on 23rd February, on Twitter you warned that a
pandemic was highly probable, if not unavoidable. In doing so, you were one of
the first government officials anywhere in the world to grasp the devastating
consequences of Corona. Since the outbreak of the pandemic has anyone from the
German government or the EU tried to contact you and talk to you about your
approach and what you’ve learned?
Sutton: I haven’t been contacted but I think, it would probably be normal practice
for national governments to speak to other national governments, so they would have
spoken our prime minister’s office.
ZEIT: If you had the chance to talk to a German politician about the situation
in Germany what would you ask?
Sutton: I guess, I wonder what their overarching objective is. What is the medium-
and long-term strategy for the German population to protect them from Covid?
